welcome.name: Welcome
welcome.content: # Welcome! Welcome to the discord.js v12 documentation. ## About discord.js is a powerful [Node.js](https://nodejs.org) module that allows you to easily interact with the [Discord API](https://discordapp.com/developers/docs/intro). - Object-oriented - Predictable abstractions - Performant - 100% coverage of the Discord API ## Installation **Node.js 12.0.0 or newer is required.** Ignore any warnings about unmet peer dependencies, as they're all optional. Without voice support: `npm install discord.js` With voice support ([@discordjs/opus](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@discordjs/opus)): `npm install discord.js @discordjs/opus` With voice support ([opusscript](https://www.npmjs.com/package/opusscript)): `npm install discord.js opusscript` ### Audio engines The preferred audio engine is @discordjs/opus, as it performs significantly better than opusscript. When both are available, discord.js will automatically choose @discordjs/opus. Using opusscript is only recommended for development environments where @discordjs/opus is tough to get working. For production bots, using @discordjs/opus should be considered a necessity, especially if they're going to be running on multiple servers. ### Optional packages - [zlib-sync](https://www.npmjs.com/package/zlib-sync) for WebSocket data compression and inflation (`npm install zlib-sync`) - [erlpack](https://github.com/discordapp/erlpack) for significantly faster WebSocket data (de)serialisation (`npm install discordapp/erlpack`) - One of the following packages can be installed for faster voice packet encryption and decryption: - [sodium](https://www.npmjs.com/package/sodium) (`npm install sodium`) - [libsodium.js](https://www.npmjs.com/package/libsodium-wrappers) (`npm install libsodium-wrappers`) - [bufferutil](https://www.npmjs.com/package/bufferutil) for a much faster WebSocket connection (`npm install bufferutil`) - [utf-8-validate](https://www.npmjs.com/package/utf-8-validate) in combination with `bufferutil` for much faster WebSocket processing (`npm install utf-8-validate`) ## Example usage ```js const Discord = require('discord.js'); const client = new Discord.Client(); client.on('ready', () => { console.log(`Logged in as ${client.user.tag}!`); }); client.on('message', msg => { if (msg.content === 'ping') { msg.reply('pong'); } }); client.login('token'); ``` ## Links - [Website](https://discord.js.org/) ([source](https://github.com/discordjs/website)) - [Documentation](https://discord.js.org/#/docs/main/master/general/welcome) - [Guide](https://discordjs.guide/) ([source](https://github.com/discordjs/guide)) - this is still for stable See also the WIP [Update Guide](https://discordjs.guide/additional-info/changes-in-v12.html) also including updated and removed items in the library. - [Discord.js Discord server](https://discord.gg/bRCvFy9) - [Discord API Discord server](https://discord.gg/discord-api) - [GitHub](https://github.com/discordjs/discord.js) - [NPM](https://www.npmjs.com/package/discord.js) - [Related libraries](https://discordapi.com/unofficial/libs.html) ### Extensions - [RPC](https://www.npmjs.com/package/discord-rpc) ([source](https://github.com/discordjs/RPC)) ## Contributing Before creating an issue, please ensure that it hasn't already been reported/suggested, and double-check the [documentation](https://discord.js.org/#/docs). See [the contribution guide](https://github.com/discordjs/discord.js/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md) if you'd like to submit a PR. ## Help If you don't understand something in the documentation, you are experiencing problems, or you just need a gentle nudge in the right direction, please don't hesitate to join our official [Discord.js Server](https://discord.gg/bRCvFy9).

updating.name: Updating your code
updating.content:
# Version 12.0.0

v12.0.0 contains many new and improved features, optimisations, and bug fixes.
See [the changelog](https://github.com/discordjs/discord.js/releases/tag/12.0.0) for a full list of changes.
You can also visit [the guide](https://discordjs.guide/additional-info/changes-in-v12.html) for help with updating your v11 code to v12.

# Version 11.1.0

v11.1.0 features improved voice and gateway stability, as well as support for new features such as audit logs and searching for messages.
See [the changelog](https://github.com/discordjs/discord.js/releases/tag/11.1.0) for a full list of changes, including
information about deprecations.

# Version 11

Version 11 contains loads of new and improved features, optimisations, and bug fixes.
See [the changelog](https://github.com/discordjs/discord.js/releases/tag/11.0.0) for a full list of changes.

## Significant additions

- Message Reactions and Embeds (rich text)
- Support for uws and erlpack for better performance
- OAuthApplication support
- Web distributions

## Breaking changes

### Client.login() no longer supports logging in with email + password

Logging in with an email and password has always been heavily discouraged since the advent of proper token support, but in v11 we have made the decision to completely remove the functionality, since Hammer & Chisel have [officially stated](https://github.com/hammerandchisel/discord-api-docs/issues/69#issuecomment-223886862) it simply shouldn't be done.

User accounts can still log in with tokens just like bot accounts. To obtain the token for a user account, you can log in to Discord with that account, and use Ctrl + Shift + I to open the developer tools. In the console tab, evaluating `localStorage.token` will give you the token for that account.

### ClientUser.setEmail()/setPassword() now require the current password, as well as setUsername() on user accounts

Since you can no longer log in with email and password, you must provide the current account password to the `setEmail()`, `setPassword()`, and `setUsername()` methods for user accounts (self-bots).

### Removed TextBasedChannel.sendTTSMessage()

This method was deemed to be an entirely pointless shortcut that virtually nobody even used.
The same results can be achieved by passing options to `send()` or `sendMessage()`.

Example:

```js
channel.send('Hi there', { tts: true });
```

### Using Collection.find()/exists() with IDs will throw an error

This is simply to help prevent a common mistake that is made frequently.
To find something or check its existence using an ID, you should use `.get()` and `.has()` which are part of the [ES6 Map class](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Map), which Collection is an extension of.

# Version 10

Version 10's non-BC changes focus on cleaning up some inconsistencies that exist in previous versions.
Upgrading from v9 should be quick and painless.

## Client options

All client options have been converted to camelCase rather than snake_case, and `max_message_cache` was renamed to `messageCacheMaxSize`.

v9 code example:

```js
const client = new Discord.Client({
  disable_everyone: true,
  max_message_cache: 500,
  message_cache_lifetime: 120,
  message_sweep_interval: 60,
});
```

v10 code example:

```js
const client = new Discord.Client({
  disableEveryone: true,
  messageCacheMaxSize: 500,
  messageCacheLifetime: 120,
  messageSweepInterval: 60,
});
```

## Presences

Presences have been completely restructured.
Previous versions of discord.js assumed that users had the same presence amongst all guilds - with the introduction of sharding, however, this is no longer the case.

v9 discord.js code may look something like this:

```js
User.status; // the status of the user
User.game; // the game that the user is playing
ClientUser.setStatus(status, game, url); // set the new status for the user
```

v10 moves presences to GuildMember instances. For the sake of simplicity, though, User classes also expose presences.
When accessing a presence on a User object, it simply finds the first GuildMember for the user, and uses its presence.
Additionally, the introduction of the Presence class keeps all of the presence data organised.

**It is strongly recommended that you use a GuildMember's presence where available, rather than a User.
A user may have an entirely different presence between two different guilds.**

v10 code:

```js
MemberOrUser.presence.status; // the status of the member or user
MemberOrUser.presence.game; // the game that the member or user is playing
ClientUser.setStatus(status); // online, idle, dnd, offline
ClientUser.setGame(game, streamingURL); // a game
ClientUser.setPresence(fullPresence); // status and game combined
```

## Voice

Voice has been rewritten internally, but in a backwards-compatible manner.
There is only one breaking change here; the `disconnected` event was renamed to `disconnect`.
Several more events have been made available to a VoiceConnection, so see the documentation.

## Events

Many events have been renamed or had their arguments change.

### Client events

| Version 9                                      | Version 10                              |
| ---------------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------- |
| guildMemberAdd(guild, member)                  | guildMemberAdd(member)                  |
| guildMemberAvailable(guild, member)            | guildMemberAvailable(member)            |
| guildMemberRemove(guild, member)               | guildMemberRemove(member)               |
| guildMembersChunk(guild, members)              | guildMembersChunk(members)              |
| guildMemberUpdate(guild, oldMember, newMember) | guildMemberUpdate(oldMember, newMember) |
| guildRoleCreate(guild, role)                   | roleCreate(role)                        |
| guildRoleDelete(guild, role)                   | roleDelete(role)                        |
| guildRoleUpdate(guild, oldRole, newRole)       | roleUpdate(oldRole, newRole)            |

The guild parameter that has been dropped from the guild-related events can still be derived using `member.guild` or `role.guild`.

### VoiceConnection events

| Version 9    | Version 10 |
| ------------ | ---------- |
| disconnected | disconnect |

## Dates and timestamps

All dates/timestamps on the structures have been refactored to have a consistent naming scheme and availability.
All of them are named similarly to this:  
**Date:** `Message.createdAt`  
**Timestamp:** `Message.createdTimestamp`  
See the docs for each structure to see which date/timestamps are available on them.

# Version 9

The version 9 (v9) rewrite takes a much more object-oriented approach than previous versions,
which allows your code to be much more readable and manageable.
It's been rebuilt from the ground up and should be much more stable, fixing caching issues that affected
older versions. It also has support for newer Discord Features, such as emojis.

Version 9, while containing a sizable number of breaking changes, does not require much change in your code's logic -
most of the concepts are still the same, but loads of functions have been moved around.
The vast majority of methods you're used to using have been moved out of the Client class,
into other more relevant classes where they belong.
Because of this, you will need to convert most of your calls over to the new methods.

Here are a few examples of methods that have changed:

- `Client.sendMessage(channel, message)` ==> `TextChannel.sendMessage(message)`
  - `Client.sendMessage(user, message)` ==> `User.sendMessage(message)`
- `Client.updateMessage(message, "New content")` ==> `Message.edit("New Content")`
- `Client.getChannelLogs(channel, limit)` ==> `TextChannel.fetchMessages({options})`
- `Server.detailsOfUser(User)` ==> `Server.members.get(User).properties` (retrieving a member gives a GuildMember object)
- `Client.joinVoiceChannel(voicechannel)` => `VoiceChannel.join()`

A couple more important details:

- `Client.loginWithToken("token")` ==> `client.login("token")`
- `Client.servers.length` ==> `client.guilds.size` (all instances of `server` are now `guild`)

## No more callbacks!

Version 9 eschews callbacks in favour of Promises. This means all code relying on callbacks must be changed.  
For example, the following code:

```js
client.getChannelLogs(channel, 100, function(messages) {
  console.log(`${messages.length} messages found`);
});
```

```js
channel.fetchMessages({ limit: 100 }).then(messages => {
  console.log(`${messages.size} messages found`);
});
```

faq.name: FAQ
faq.content:
# Frequently Asked Questions

These questions are some of the most frequently asked.

## No matter what, I get `SyntaxError: Block-scoped declarations (let, const, function, class) not yet supported outside strict mode`â€½

Update to Node.js 12.0.0 or newer.

## How do I get voice working?

- Install FFMPEG.
- Install either the `@discordjs/opus` package or the `opusscript` package.
  @discordjs/opus is greatly preferred, due to it having significantly better performance.

## How do I install FFMPEG?

- **npm:** `npm install ffmpeg-binaries`
- **Ubuntu 16.04:** `sudo apt install ffmpeg`
- **Ubuntu 14.04:** `sudo apt-get install libav-tools`
- **Windows:** `npm install ffmpeg-binaries` or see the [FFMPEG section of AoDude's guide](https://github.com/bdistin/OhGodMusicBot/blob/master/README.md#download-ffmpeg).

## How do I set up @discordjs/opus?

- **Ubuntu:** Simply run `npm install @discordjs/opus`, and it's done. Congrats!
- **Windows:** Run `npm install --global --production windows-build-tools` in an admin command prompt or PowerShell.
  Then, running `npm install @discordjs/opus` in your bot's directory should successfully build it. Woo!

Other questions can be found at the [official Discord.js guide](https://discordjs.guide/popular-topics/common-questions.html)
If you have issues not listed here or on the guide, feel free to ask in the [official Discord.js server](https://discord.gg/bRCvFy9).
Always make sure to read the [documentation](https://discord.js.org/#/docs/main/stable/general/welcome).

web.name: Web builds
web.content:
# Web builds

In addition to your usual Node applications, discord.js has special distributions available that are capable of running in web browsers.
This is useful for client-side web apps that need to interact with the Discord API.
[Webpack 3](https://webpack.js.org/) is used to build these.

## Restrictions

- Any voice-related functionality is unavailable, as there is currently no audio encoding/decoding capabilities without external native libraries,
  which web browsers do not support.
- The ShardingManager cannot be used, since it relies on being able to spawn child processes for shards.
- None of the native optional packages are usable.

### Require Library

If you are making your own webpack project, you can require `discord.js/browser` wherever you need to use discord.js, like so:

```js
const Discord = require('discord.js/browser');
// do something with Discord like you normally would
```

### Webpack File

You can obtain your desired version of discord.js' web build from the [webpack branch](https://github.com/discordjs/discord.js/tree/webpack) of the GitHub repository.
There is a file for each branch and version of the library, and the ones ending in `.min.js` are minified to substantially reduce the size of the source code.

Include the file on the page just as you would any other JS library, like so:

```html
<script type="text/javascript" src="discord.VERSION.min.js"></script>
```

Rather than importing discord.js with `require('discord.js')`, the entire `Discord` object is available as a global (on the `window`) object.
The usage of the API isn't any different from using it in Node.js.

#### Example

```html
<script type="text/javascript" src="discord.11.1.0.min.js"></script>
<script type="text/javascript">
  const client = new Discord.Client();

  client.on('message', msg => {
    const guildTag = msg.channel.type === 'text' ? `[${msg.guild.name}]` : '[DM]';
    const channelTag = msg.channel.type === 'text' ? `[#${msg.channel.name}]` : '';
    console.log(`${guildTag}${channelTag} ${msg.author.tag}: ${msg.content}`);
  });

  client.login('some crazy token');
</script>
```

classes.name: BaseClient
classes.description: The base class for all clients.

props.name: _timeouts
props.description: Timeouts set by {@link BaseClient#setTimeout} that are still active

props.name: _intervals
props.description: Intervals set by {@link BaseClient#setInterval} that are still active

props.name: _immediates
props.description: Intervals set by {@link BaseClient#setImmediate} that are still active

props.name: options
props.description: The options the client was instantiated with

props.name: rest
props.description: The REST manager of the client

props.name: api
props.description: API shortcut

methods.name: destroy
methods.description: Destroys all assets used by the base client.

methods.name: setTimeout
methods.description: Sets a timeout that will be automatically cancelled if the client is destroyed.

params.name: delay
params.description: Time to wait before executing (in milliseconds)

methods.name: clearTimeout
methods.description: Clears a timeout.

methods.name: setInterval
methods.description: Sets an interval that will be automatically cancelled if the client is destroyed.

params.name: delay
params.description: Time to wait between executions (in milliseconds)

methods.name: clearInterval
methods.description: Clears an interval.

methods.name: setImmediate
methods.description: Sets an immediate that will be automatically cancelled if the client is destroyed.

methods.name: clearImmediate
methods.description: Clears an immediate.

classes.name: Client
classes.description: The main hub for interacting with the Discord API, and the starting point for any bot.

props.name: ws
props.description: The WebSocket manager of the client

props.name: actions
props.description: The action manager of the client

props.name: voice
props.description: The voice manager of the client (`null` in browsers)

props.name: shard
props.description: Shard helpers for the client (only if the process was spawned from a {@link ShardingManager})

props.name: users
props.description: All of the {@link User} objects that have been cached at any point, mapped by their IDs

props.name: guilds
props.description:
All of the guilds the client is currently handling, mapped by their IDs -
as long as sharding isn't being used, this will be *every* guild the bot is a member of

props.name: channels
props.description:
All of the {@link Channel}s that the client is currently handling, mapped by their IDs -
as long as sharding isn't being used, this will be *every* channel in *every* guild the bot
is a member of. Note that DM channels will not be initially cached, and thus not be present
in the Manager without their explicit fetching or use.

props.name: presence
props.description: The presence of the Client

props.name: token
props.description:
Authorization token for the logged in bot
<warn>This should be kept private at all times.</warn>

props.name: user
props.description: User that the client is logged in as

props.name: readyAt
props.description:
Time at which the client was last regarded as being in the `READY` state
(each time the client disconnects and successfully reconnects, this will be overwritten)

props.name: emojis
props.description: All custom emojis that the client has access to, mapped by their IDs

props.name: readyTimestamp
props.description: Timestamp of the time the client was last `READY` at

props.name: uptime
props.description: How long it has been since the client last entered the `READY` state in milliseconds

props.name: _timeouts
props.description: Timeouts set by {@link BaseClient#setTimeout} that are still active

props.name: _intervals
props.description: Intervals set by {@link BaseClient#setInterval} that are still active

props.name: _immediates
props.description: Intervals set by {@link BaseClient#setImmediate} that are still active

props.name: options
props.description: The options the client was instantiated with

props.name: rest
props.description: The REST manager of the client

props.name: api
props.description: API shortcut

methods.name: login
methods.description: Logs the client in, establishing a websocket connection to Discord.
examples: client.login('my token');

params.name: token
params.description: Token of the account to log in with

returns.description: Token of the account used

methods.name: destroy
methods.description: Logs out, terminates the connection to Discord, and destroys the client.

methods.name: fetchInvite
methods.description: Obtains an invite from Discord.

methods.name: fetchWebhook
methods.description: Obtains a webhook from Discord.

methods.name: fetchVoiceRegions
methods.description: Obtains the available voice regions from Discord.

methods.name: sweepMessages
methods.description:
Sweeps all text-based channels' messages and removes the ones older than the max message lifetime.
If the message has been edited, the time of the edit is used rather than the time of the original message.

params.name: lifetime
params.description:
Messages that are older than this (in seconds)
will be removed from the caches. The default is based on {@link ClientOptions#messageCacheLifetime}

returns.description:
Amount of messages that were removed from the caches,
or -1 if the message cache lifetime is unlimited

methods.name: fetchApplication
methods.description: Obtains the OAuth Application of this bot from Discord.

methods.name: generateInvite
methods.description: Generates a link that can be used to invite the bot to a guild.

methods.name: _eval
methods.description:
Calls {@link https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/eval} on a script
with the client as `this`.

methods.name: _validateOptions
methods.description: Validates the client options.

methods.name: setTimeout
methods.description: Sets a timeout that will be automatically cancelled if the client is destroyed.

params.name: delay
params.description: Time to wait before executing (in milliseconds)

methods.name: clearTimeout
methods.description: Clears a timeout.

methods.name: setInterval
methods.description: Sets an interval that will be automatically cancelled if the client is destroyed.

params.name: delay
params.description: Time to wait between executions (in milliseconds)

methods.name: clearInterval
methods.description: Clears an interval.

methods.name: setImmediate
methods.description: Sets an immediate that will be automatically cancelled if the client is destroyed.

methods.name: clearImmediate
methods.description: Clears an immediate.

events.name: channelCreate
events.description: Emitted whenever a channel is created.

events.name: channelDelete
events.description: Emitted whenever a channel is deleted.

events.name: guildBanRemove
events.description: Emitted whenever a member is unbanned from a guild.

params.name: guild
params.description: The guild that the unban occurred in

events.name: guildUnavailable
events.description: Emitted whenever a guild becomes unavailable, likely due to a server outage.

params.name: guild
params.description: The guild that has become unavailable

events.name: guildDelete
events.description: Emitted whenever a guild kicks the client or the guild is deleted/left.

events.name: emojiCreate
events.description: Emitted whenever a custom emoji is created in a guild.

events.name: emojiDelete
events.description: Emitted whenever a custom emoji is deleted in a guild.

events.name: emojiUpdate
events.description: Emitted whenever a custom emoji is updated in a guild.

events.name: guildIntegrationsUpdate
events.description: Emitted whenever a guild integration is updated

params.name: guild
params.description: The guild whose integrations were updated

events.name: guildMemberRemove
events.description: Emitted whenever a member leaves a guild, or is kicked.

params.name: member
params.description: The member that has left/been kicked from the guild

events.name: roleCreate
events.description: Emitted whenever a role is created.

events.name: roleDelete
events.description: Emitted whenever a guild role is deleted.

events.name: roleUpdate
events.description: Emitted whenever a guild role is updated.

events.name: guildUpdate
events.description: Emitted whenever a guild is updated - e.g. name change.

events.name: inviteCreate
events.description:
Emitted when an invite is created.
<info> This event only triggers if the client has `MANAGE_GUILD` permissions for the guild,
or `MANAGE_CHANNEL` permissions for the channel.</info>

events.name: inviteDelete
events.description:
Emitted when an invite is deleted.
<info> This event only triggers if the client has `MANAGE_GUILD` permissions for the guild,
or `MANAGE_CHANNEL` permissions for the channel.</info>

events.name: message
events.description: Emitted whenever a message is created.

events.name: messageDelete
events.description: Emitted whenever a message is deleted.

events.name: messageDeleteBulk
events.description: Emitted whenever messages are deleted in bulk.

params.name: messages
params.description: The deleted messages, mapped by their ID

events.name: messageReactionAdd
events.description: Emitted whenever a reaction is added to a cached message.

params.name: user
params.description: The user that applied the guild or reaction emoji

events.name: messageReactionRemove
events.description: Emitted whenever a reaction is removed from a cached message.

params.name: user
params.description: The user whose emoji or reaction emoji was removed

events.name: messageReactionRemoveAll
events.description: Emitted whenever all reactions are removed from a cached message.

params.name: message
params.description: The message the reactions were removed from

events.name: messageReactionRemoveEmoji
events.description: Emitted when a bot removes an emoji reaction from a cached message.

events.name: presenceUpdate
events.description: Emitted whenever a guild member's presence (e.g. status, activity) is changed.

params.name: oldPresence
params.description: The presence before the update, if one at all

events.name: userUpdate
events.description: Emitted whenever a user's details (e.g. username) are changed.

events.name: voiceStateUpdate
events.description: Emitted whenever a member changes voice state - e.g. joins/leaves a channel, mutes/unmutes.

params.name: oldState
params.description: The voice state before the update

params.name: newState
params.description: The voice state after the update

events.name: webhookUpdate
events.description: Emitted whenever a guild text channel has its webhooks changed.

params.name: channel
params.description: The channel that had a webhook update

events.name: warn
events.description: Emitted for general warnings.

events.name: debug
events.description: Emitted for general debugging information.

events.name: guildMemberSpeaking
events.description: Emitted once a guild member changes speaking state.

params.name: speaking
params.description: The speaking state of the member

events.name: channelPinsUpdate
events.description:
Emitted whenever the pins of a channel are updated. Due to the nature of the WebSocket event,
not much information can be provided easily here - you need to manually check the pins yourself.

params.name: channel
params.description: The channel that the pins update occurred in

params.name: time
params.description: The time of the pins update

events.name: channelUpdate
events.description: Emitted whenever a channel is updated - e.g. name change, topic change, channel type change.

events.name: guildBanAdd
events.description: Emitted whenever a member is banned from a guild.

params.name: guild
params.description: The guild that the ban occurred in

events.name: guildCreate
events.description: Emitted whenever the client joins a guild.

events.name: guildMemberAdd
events.description: Emitted whenever a user joins a guild.

params.name: member
params.description: The member that has joined a guild

events.name: guildMemberUpdate
events.description: Emitted whenever a guild member changes - i.e. new role, removed role, nickname.

events.name: guildMembersChunk
events.description: Emitted whenever a chunk of guild members is received (all members come from the same guild).

params.name: guild
params.description: The guild related to the member chunk

events.name: messageUpdate
events.description: Emitted whenever a message is updated - e.g. embed or content change.

events.name: shardResume
events.description: Emitted when a shard resumes successfully.

events.name: typingStart
events.description: Emitted whenever a user starts typing in a channel.

params.name: channel
params.description: The channel the user started typing in

events.name: shardReady
events.description: Emitted when a shard turns ready.

params.name: id
params.description: The shard ID that turned ready

params.name: unavailableGuilds
params.description: Set of unavailable guild IDs, if any

events.name: shardDisconnect
events.description: Emitted when a shard's WebSocket disconnects and will no longer reconnect.

events.name: shardReconnecting
events.description: Emitted when a shard is attempting to reconnect or re-identify.

params.name: id
params.description: The shard ID that is attempting to reconnect

events.name: invalidated
events.description:
Emitted when the client's session becomes invalidated.
You are expected to handle closing the process gracefully and preventing a boot loop
if you are listening to this event.

events.name: ready
events.description: Emitted when the client becomes ready to start working.

events.name: shardError

<info>This class forwards raw dispatch events,
read more about it here {@link https://discordapp.com/developers/docs/topics/gateway}</info>

props.name: client
props.description: The client that instantiated this WebSocketManager

props.description: The gateway this manager uses

props.description: The amount of shards this manager handles

props.description: A collection of all shards this manager handles

props.name: shardQueue
props.description: An array of shards to be connected or that need to reconnect

props.name: packetQueue
props.description: An array of queued events before this WebSocketManager became ready

props.name: status
props.description: The current status of this WebSocketManager

props.name: destroyed
props.description: If this manager was destroyed. It will prevent shards from reconnecting

props.name: reconnecting
props.description: If this manager is currently reconnecting one or multiple shards

props.name: sessionStartLimit
props.description: The current session limit of the client

props.name: total
props.description: Total number of identifies available

props.name: remaining
props.description: Number of identifies remaining

props.name: reset_after
props.description: Number of milliseconds after which the limit resets

props.name: ping
props.description: The average ping of all WebSocketShards

methods.name: debug
methods.description: Emits a debug message.

params.name: shard
params.description: The shard that emitted this message, if any

methods.name: connect
methods.description: Connects this manager to the gateway.

methods.name: createShards
methods.description: Handles the creation of a shard.

methods.name: reconnect
methods.description: Handles reconnects for this manager.

params.name: skipLimit
params.description: IF this reconnect should skip checking the session limit

methods.name: broadcast
methods.description: Broadcasts a packet to every shard this manager handles.

methods.name: destroy
methods.description: Destroys this manager and all its shards.

methods.description: Handles the timeout required if we cannot identify anymore.

params.name: remaining
params.description: The amount of remaining identify sessions that can be done today

params.name: resetAfter
params.description: The amount of time in which the identify counter resets

methods.description: Processes a packet and queues it if this WebSocketManager is not ready.

params.description: The shard that will handle this packet

methods.description: Checks whether the client is ready to be marked as ready.

classes.description: Represents a Shard's WebSocket connection

props.name: manager
props.description: The WebSocketManager of the shard

props.name: id
props.description: The ID of the shard

props.name: status
props.description: The current status of the shard

props.name: sequence
props.description: The current sequence of the shard

props.name: closeSequence
props.description: The sequence of the shard after close

props.name: sessionID
props.description: The current session ID of the shard

props.name: ping
props.description: The previous heartbeat ping of the shard

props.name: lastPingTimestamp
props.description: The last time a ping was sent (a timestamp)

props.name: lastHeartbeatAcked
props.description: If we received a heartbeat ack back. Used to identify zombie connections

methods.name: debug
methods.description: Emits a debug event.

methods.name: connect
methods.description: Connects the shard to the gateway.

returns.description:
A promise that will resolve if the shard turns ready successfully,
or reject if we couldn't connect

methods.name: onOpen
methods.description: Called whenever a connection is opened to the gateway.

methods.name: onMessage
methods.description: Called whenever a message is received.

methods.name: onError
methods.description: Called whenever an error occurs with the WebSocket.

methods.name: onClose
methods.description: Called whenever a connection to the gateway is closed.

methods.name: onPacket
methods.description: Called whenever a packet is received.

methods.name: checkReady
methods.description: Checks if the shard can be marked as ready

methods.name: setHelloTimeout
methods.description: Sets the HELLO packet timeout.

params.name: time
params.description: If set to -1, it will clear the hello timeout timeout

methods.name: setHeartbeatTimer
methods.description: Sets the heartbeat timer for this shard.

params.name: time
params.description: If -1, clears the interval, any other number sets an interval

methods.name: sendHeartbeat
methods.description:
Sends a heartbeat to the WebSocket.
If this shard didn't receive a heartbeat last time, it will destroy it and reconnect

params.name: tag
params.description: What caused this heartbeat to be sent

params.name: ignoreHeartbeatAck
params.description: If we should send the heartbeat forcefully.

methods.name: ackHeartbeat
methods.description: Acknowledges a heartbeat.

methods.name: identify
methods.description: Identifies the client on the connection.

methods.name: identifyNew
methods.description: Identifies as a new connection on the gateway.

methods.name: identifyResume
methods.description: Resumes a session on the gateway.

methods.name: send
methods.description:
Adds a packet to the queue to be sent to the gateway.
<warn>If you use this method, make sure you understand that you need to provide
a full [Payload](https://discordapp.com/developers/docs/topics/gateway#commands-and-events-gateway-commands).
Do not use this method if you don't know what you're doing.</warn>

params.name: important
params.description: If this packet should be added first in queue

methods.name: _send
methods.description: Sends data, bypassing the queue.

methods.name: processQueue
methods.description: Processes the current WebSocket queue.

methods.name: destroy
methods.description: Destroys this shard and closes its WebSocket connection.

params.name: options
params.default: { closeCode: 1000, reset: false, emit: true, log: true }

methods.name: _cleanupConnection
methods.description: Cleans up the WebSocket connection listeners.

methods.name: _emitDestroyed
methods.description: Emits the DESTROYED event on the shard

events.name: close
events.description: Emitted when a shard's WebSocket closes.

events.name: ready
events.description: Emitted when the shard receives the READY payload and is now waiting for guilds

events.name: resumed
events.description: Emitted when the shard resumes successfully

events.name: allReady
events.description:
Emitted when the shard is fully ready.
This event is emitted if:
* all guilds were received by this shard
* the ready timeout expired, and some guilds are unavailable

params.name: unavailableGuilds
params.description: Set of unavailable guilds, if any

events.name: destroyed
events.description: Emitted when a shard is destroyed, but no WebSocket connection was present.

classes.name: Shard
classes.description:
A self-contained shard created by the {@link ShardingManager}. Each one has a {@link ChildProcess} that contains
an instance of the bot and its {@link Client}. When its child process/worker exits for any reason, the shard will
spawn a new one to replace it as necessary.

params.name: manager
params.description: Manager that is spawning this shard

props.name: manager
props.description: Manager that created the shard

props.name: id
props.description: ID of the shard in the manager

props.name: args
props.description: Arguments for the shard's process (only when {@link ShardingManager#mode} is `process`)

props.name: execArgv
props.description: Arguments for the shard's process executable (only when {@link ShardingManager#mode} is `process`)

props.name: env
props.description: Environment variables for the shard's process, or workerData for the shard's worker

props.name: ready
props.description: Whether the shard's {@link Client} is ready

props.name: process
props.description: Process of the shard (if {@link ShardingManager#mode} is `process`)

props.name: worker
props.description: Worker of the shard (if {@link ShardingManager#mode} is `worker`)

props.name: _evals
props.description: Ongoing promises for calls to {@link Shard#eval}, mapped by the `script` they were called with

props.name: _fetches
props.description: Ongoing promises for calls to {@link Shard#fetchClientValue}, mapped by the `prop` they were called with

props.name: _exitListener
props.description: Listener function for the {@link ChildProcess}' `exit` event

methods.name: spawn
methods.description:
Forks a child process or creates a worker thread for the shard.
<warn>You should not need to call this manually.</warn>

params.name: spawnTimeout
params.description:
The amount in milliseconds to wait until the {@link Client} has become ready
before resolving. (-1 or Infinity for no wait)

methods.name: kill
methods.description: Immediately kills the shard's process/worker and does not restart it.

methods.name: respawn
methods.description: Kills and restarts the shard's process/worker.

params.name: delay
params.description: How long to wait between killing the process/worker and restarting it (in milliseconds)

params.name: spawnTimeout
params.description:
The amount in milliseconds to wait until the {@link Client} has become ready
before resolving. (-1 or Infinity for no wait)

methods.name: send
methods.description: Sends a message to the shard's process/worker.

params.name: message
params.description: Message to send to the shard

methods.name: fetchClientValue
methods.description: Fetches a client property value of the shard.

params.name: prop
params.description: Name of the client property to get, using periods for nesting

methods.name: eval
methods.description: Evaluates a script or function on the shard, in the context of the {@link Client}.

params.name: script
params.description: JavaScript to run on the shard

returns.description: Result of the script execution

methods.name: _handleMessage
methods.description: Handles a message received from the child process/worker.

methods.name: _handleExit
methods.description: Handles the shard's process/worker exiting.

params.name: respawn
params.description: Whether to spawn the shard again

events.name: spawn
events.description: Emitted upon the creation of the shard's child process/worker.

events.name: ready
events.description: Emitted upon the shard's {@link Client#ready} event.

events.name: disconnect
events.description: Emitted upon the shard's {@link Client#disconnect} event.

events.name: reconnecting
events.description: Emitted upon the shard's {@link Client#reconnecting} event.

events.name: message
events.description: Emitted upon receiving a message from the child process/worker.

events.name: death
events.description: Emitted upon the shard's child process/worker exiting.

classes.name: ShardingManager
classes.description:
This is a utility class that makes multi-process sharding of a bot an easy and painless experience.
It works by spawning a self-contained {@link ChildProcess} or {@link Worker} for each individual shard, each
containing its own instance of your bot's {@link Client}. They all have a line of communication with the master
process, and there are several useful methods that utilise it in order to simplify tasks that are normally difficult
with sharding. It can spawn a specific number of shards or the amount that Discord suggests for the bot, and takes a
path to your main bot script to launch for each one.

params.name: file
params.description: Path to your shard script file

params.name: options.totalShards
params.description: Number of total shards of all shard managers or "auto"

params.name: options.shardList
params.description: List of shards to spawn or "auto"

params.name: options.mode
params.description: Which mode to use for shards

params.name: options.respawn
params.description: Whether shards should automatically respawn upon exiting

params.name: options.shardArgs
params.description:
Arguments to pass to the shard script when spawning
(only available when using the `process` mode)

params.name: options.execArgv
params.description:
Arguments to pass to the shard script executable when spawning
(only available when using the `process` mode)

params.name: options.token
params.description: Token to use for automatic shard count and passing to shards

props.name: file
props.description: Path to the shard script file

props.name: shardList
props.description: List of shards this sharding manager spawns

props.name: totalShards
props.description: Amount of shards that all sharding managers spawn in total

props.name: mode
props.description: Mode for shards to spawn with

props.name: respawn
props.description: Whether shards should automatically respawn upon exiting

props.name: shardArgs
props.description: An array of arguments to pass to shards (only when {@link ShardingManager#mode} is `process`)

props.name: execArgv
props.description: An array of arguments to pass to the executable (only when {@link ShardingManager#mode} is `process`)

props.name: token
props.description: Token to use for obtaining the automatic shard count, and passing to shards

props.name: shards
props.description: A collection of shards that this manager has spawned

ID of the shard to spawn -
**This is usually not necessary to manually specify.**

(in milliseconds)

methods.name: startTyping
methods.description: Starts a typing indicator in the channel.
examples:
// Start typing in a channel, or increase the typing count by one
channel.startTyping();

// Start typing in a channel with a typing count of five, or set it to five
channel.startTyping(5);

params.name: count
params.description: The number of times startTyping should be considered to have been called

returns.description: Resolves once the bot stops typing gracefully, or rejects when an error occurs

methods.name: stopTyping
methods.description:
Stops the typing indicator in the channel.
The indicator will only stop if this is called as many times as startTyping().
<info>It can take a few seconds for the client user to stop typing.</info>
examples:
// Reduce the typing count by one and stop typing if it reached 0
channel.stopTyping();

// Force typing to fully stop regardless of typing count
channel.stopTyping(true);

params.name: force
params.description: Whether or not to reset the call count and force the indicator to stop

props.description: Number of times `startTyping` has been called

methods.description: Sends a message to this channel.

methods.name: startTyping
methods.description: Starts a typing indicator in the channel.
examples:
// Start typing in a channel, or increase the typing count by one
channel.startTyping();

// Start typing in a channel with a typing count of five, or set it to five
channel.startTyping(5);

params.name: count
params.description: The number of times startTyping should be considered to have been called

returns.description: Resolves once the bot stops typing gracefully, or rejects when an error occurs

methods.name: stopTyping
methods.description:
Stops the typing indicator in the channel.
The indicator will only stop if this is called as many times as startTyping().
<info>It can take a few seconds for the client user to stop typing.</info>
examples:
// Reduce the typing count by one and stop typing if it reached 0
channel.stopTyping();

// Force typing to fully stop regardless of typing count
channel.stopTyping(true);

params.name: force
params.description: Whether or not to reset the call count and force the indicator to stop

methods.description: Starts a typing indicator in the channel.
examples:
// Start typing in a channel, or increase the typing count by one
channel.startTyping();

// Start typing in a channel with a typing count of five, or set it to five
channel.startTyping(5);

params.name: count
params.description: The number of times startTyping should be considered to have been called

returns.description: Resolves once the bot stops typing gracefully, or rejects when an error occurs

methods.name: stopTyping
methods.description:
Stops the typing indicator in the channel.
The indicator will only stop if this is called as many times as startTyping().
<info>It can take a few seconds for the client user to stop typing.</info>
examples:
// Reduce the typing count by one and stop typing if it reached 0
channel.stopTyping();

// Force typing to fully stop regardless of typing count
channel.stopTyping(true);

params.name: force
params.description: Whether or not to reset the call count and force the indicator to stop

Represents a limited emoji set used for both custom and unicode emojis. Custom emojis
will use this class opposed to the Emoji class when the client doesn't know enough
information about them.

instead of the Emoji object.

The indicator will only stop if this is called as many times as startTyping().
<info>It can take a few seconds for the client user to stop typing.</info>

// Reduce the typing count by one and stop typing if it reached 0

// Force typing to fully stop regardless of typing count
channel.stopTyping(true);

classes.name: Permissions
classes.description:
Data structure that makes it easy to interact with a permission bitfield. All {@link GuildMember}s have a set of
permissions in their guild, and each channel in the guild may also have {@link PermissionOverwrites} for the member
that override their default permissions.

props.name: bitfield
props.description: Bitfield of the packed bits

props.name: FLAGS
props.description:
Numeric permission flags. All available properties:
* `ADMINISTRATOR` (implicitly has *all* permissions, and bypasses all channel overwrites)
* `CREATE_INSTANT_INVITE` (create invitations to the guild)
* `KICK_MEMBERS`
* `BAN_MEMBERS`
* `MANAGE_CHANNELS` (edit and reorder channels)
* `MANAGE_GUILD` (edit the guild information, region, etc.)
* `ADD_REACTIONS` (add new reactions to messages)
* `VIEW_AUDIT_LOG`
* `PRIORITY_SPEAKER`
* `STREAM`
* `VIEW_CHANNEL`
* `SEND_MESSAGES`
* `SEND_TTS_MESSAGES`
* `MANAGE_MESSAGES` (delete messages and reactions)
* `EMBED_LINKS` (links posted will have a preview embedded)
* `ATTACH_FILES`
* `READ_MESSAGE_HISTORY` (view messages that were posted prior to opening Discord)
* `MENTION_EVERYONE`
* `USE_EXTERNAL_EMOJIS` (use emojis from different guilds)
* `CONNECT` (connect to a voice channel)
* `SPEAK` (speak in a voice channel)
* `MUTE_MEMBERS` (mute members across all voice channels)
* `DEAFEN_MEMBERS` (deafen members across all voice channels)
* `MOVE_MEMBERS` (move members between voice channels)
* `USE_VAD` (use voice activity detection)
* `CHANGE_NICKNAME`
* `MANAGE_NICKNAMES` (change other members' nicknames)
* `MANAGE_ROLES`
* `MANAGE_WEBHOOKS`
* `MANAGE_EMOJIS`

props.name: ALL
props.description: Bitfield representing every permission combined

props.name: DEFAULT
props.description: Bitfield representing the default permissions for users

typedefs.name: ReceiveStreamOptions
typedefs.description: Options passed to `VoiceReceiver#createStream`.

props.name: mode
props.description:
The mode for audio output. This defaults to opus, meaning discord.js won't decode
the packets for you. You can set this to 'pcm' so that the stream's output will be 16-bit little-endian stereo
audio

props.name: end
props.description:
When the stream should be destroyed. If `silence`, this will be when the user
stops talking. Otherwise, if `manual`, this should be handled by you.

typedefs.name: StreamOptions
typedefs.description: Options that can be passed to stream-playing methods:

props.name: type
props.description: The type of stream.

props.name: seek
props.description: The time to seek to, will be ignored when playing `ogg/opus` or `webm/opus` streams

props.name: volume
props.description:
The volume to play at. Set this to false to disable volume transforms for
this stream to improve performance.

props.name: plp
props.description: Expected packet loss percentage

props.name: fec
props.description: Enabled forward error correction

props.name: bitrate
props.description:
The bitrate (quality) of the audio in kbps.
If set to 'auto', the voice channel's bitrate will be used

props.name: highWaterMark
props.description:
The maximum number of opus packets to make and store before they are
actually needed. See https://nodejs.org/en/docs/guides/backpressuring-in-streams/. Setting this value to
1 means that changes in volume will be more instant.

typedefs.name: StreamType
typedefs.description:
An option passed as part of `StreamOptions` specifying the type of the stream.
* `unknown`: The default type, streams/input will be passed through to ffmpeg before encoding.
Will play most streams.
* `converted`: Play a stream of 16bit signed stereo PCM data, skipping ffmpeg.
* `opus`: Play a stream of opus packets, skipping ffmpeg. You lose the ability to alter volume.
* `ogg/opus`: Play an ogg file with the opus encoding, skipping ffmpeg. You lose the ability to alter volume.
* `webm/opus`: Play a webm file with opus audio, skipping ffmpeg. You lose the ability to alter volume.

props.name: partials
props.description:
Structures allowed to be partial. This means events can be emitted even when
they're missing all the data for a particular structure. See the "Partials" topic listed in the sidebar for some
important usage information, as partials require you to put checks in place when handling data.

props.name: restWsBridgeTimeout
props.description:
Maximum time permitted between REST responses and their
corresponding websocket events

props.name: restTimeOffset
props.description:
Extra time in millseconds to wait before continuing to make REST
requests (higher values will reduce rate-limiting errors on bad connections)

props.name: restRequestTimeout
props.description: Time to wait before cancelling a REST request, in milliseconds

props.name: restSweepInterval
props.description:
How frequently to delete inactive request buckets, in seconds
(or 0 for never)

props.name: retryLimit
props.description: How many times to retry on 5XX errors (Infinity for indefinite amount of retries)

props.name: presence
props.description: Presence data to use upon login

props.name: ws
props.description: Options for the WebSocket

props.name: http
props.description: HTTP options

typedefs.name: WebsocketOptions
typedefs.description: WebSocket options (these are left as snake_case to match the API)

props.name: large_threshold
props.description: Number of members in a guild to be considered large

props.name: intents
props.description: Intents to enable for this connection

typedefs.name: HTTPOptions
typedefs.description: HTTP options

props.name: version
props.description: API version to use

props.name: api
props.description: Base url of the API

props.name: cdn
props.description: Base url of the CDN

props.name: invite
props.description: Base url of invites

typedefs.name: ImageURLOptions
typedefs.description: Options for Image URLs.

props.name: format
props.description:
One of `webp`, `png`, `jpg`, `gif`. If no format is provided,
defaults to `webp`.

props.name: dynamic
props.description:
If true, the format will dynamically change to `gif` for
animated avatars; the default is false.

typedefs.name: Status
typedefs.description:
The current status of the client. Here are the available statuses:
* READY: 0
* CONNECTING: 1
* RECONNECTING: 2
* IDLE: 3
* NEARLY: 4
* DISCONNECTED: 5
* WAITING_FOR_GUILDS: 6
* IDENTIFYING: 7
* RESUMING: 8

typedefs.name: VoiceStatus
typedefs.description:
The current status of a voice connection. Here are the available statuses:
* CONNECTED: 0
* CONNECTING: 1
* AUTHENTICATING: 2
* RECONNECTING: 3
* DISCONNECTED: 4

typedefs.name: PartialType
typedefs.description:
The type of Structure allowed to be a partial:
* USER
* CHANNEL (only affects DMChannels)
* GUILD_MEMBER
* MESSAGE
* REACTION
<warn>Partials require you to put checks in place when handling data, read the Partials topic listed in the
sidebar for more information.</warn>

typedefs.name: WSEventType
typedefs.description:
The type of a websocket message event, e.g. `MESSAGE_CREATE`. Here are the available events:
* READY
* RESUMED
* GUILD_CREATE
* GUILD_DELETE
* GUILD_UPDATE
* INVITE_CREATE
* INVITE_DELETE
* GUILD_MEMBER_ADD
* GUILD_MEMBER_REMOVE
* GUILD_MEMBER_UPDATE
* GUILD_MEMBERS_CHUNK
* GUILD_INTEGRATIONS_UPDATE
* GUILD_ROLE_CREATE
* GUILD_ROLE_DELETE
* GUILD_ROLE_UPDATE
* GUILD_BAN_ADD
* GUILD_BAN_REMOVE
* GUILD_EMOJIS_UPDATE
* CHANNEL_CREATE
* CHANNEL_DELETE
* CHANNEL_UPDATE
* CHANNEL_PINS_UPDATE
* MESSAGE_CREATE
* MESSAGE_DELETE
* MESSAGE_UPDATE
* MESSAGE_DELETE_BULK
* MESSAGE_REACTION_ADD
* MESSAGE_REACTION_REMOVE
* MESSAGE_REACTION_REMOVE_ALL
* MESSAGE_REACTION_REMOVE_EMOJI
* USER_UPDATE
* PRESENCE_UPDATE
* TYPING_START
* VOICE_STATE_UPDATE
* VOICE_SERVER_UPDATE
* WEBHOOKS_UPDATE

typedefs.name: MessageType
typedefs.description:
The type of a message, e.g. `DEFAULT`. Here are the available types:
* DEFAULT
* RECIPIENT_ADD
* RECIPIENT_REMOVE
* CALL
* CHANNEL_NAME_CHANGE
* CHANNEL_ICON_CHANGE
* PINS_ADD
* GUILD_MEMBER_JOIN
* USER_PREMIUM_GUILD_SUBSCRIPTION
* USER_PREMIUM_GUILD_SUBSCRIPTION_TIER_1
* USER_PREMIUM_GUILD_SUBSCRIPTION_TIER_2
* USER_PREMIUM_GUILD_SUBSCRIPTION_TIER_3
* CHANNEL_FOLLOW_ADD
* GUILD_DISCOVERY_DISQUALIFIED
* GUILD_DISCOVERY_REQUALIFIED

typedefs.name: ActivityType
typedefs.description:
<info>Bots cannot set a `CUSTOM_STATUS`, it is only for custom statuses received from users</info>
The type of an activity of a users presence, e.g. `PLAYING`. Here are the available types:
* PLAYING
* STREAMING
* LISTENING
* WATCHING
* CUSTOM_STATUS

typedefs.name: ExplicitContentFilterLevel
typedefs.description:
The value set for the explicit content filter levels for a guild:
* DISABLED
* MEMBERS_WITHOUT_ROLES
* ALL_MEMBERS

typedefs.name: VerificationLevel
typedefs.description:
The value set for the verification levels for a guild:
* NONE
* LOW
* MEDIUM
* HIGH
* VERY_HIGH

typedefs.name: APIError
typedefs.description:
An error encountered while performing an API request. Here are the potential errors:
* UNKNOWN_ACCOUNT
* UNKNOWN_APPLICATION
* UNKNOWN_CHANNEL
* UNKNOWN_GUILD
* UNKNOWN_INTEGRATION
* UNKNOWN_INVITE
* UNKNOWN_MEMBER
* UNKNOWN_MESSAGE
* UNKNOWN_OVERWRITE
* UNKNOWN_PROVIDER
* UNKNOWN_ROLE
* UNKNOWN_TOKEN
* UNKNOWN_USER
* UNKNOWN_EMOJI
* UNKNOWN_WEBHOOK
* BOT_PROHIBITED_ENDPOINT
* BOT_ONLY_ENDPOINT
* MAXIMUM_GUILDS
* MAXIMUM_FRIENDS
* MAXIMUM_PINS
* MAXIMUM_ROLES
* MAXIMUM_REACTIONS
* MAXIMUM_CHANNELS
* MAXIMUM_INVITES
* UNAUTHORIZED
* USER_BANNED
* MISSING_ACCESS
* INVALID_ACCOUNT_TYPE
* CANNOT_EXECUTE_ON_DM
* EMBED_DISABLED
* CANNOT_EDIT_MESSAGE_BY_OTHER
* CANNOT_SEND_EMPTY_MESSAGE
* CANNOT_MESSAGE_USER
* CANNOT_SEND_MESSAGES_IN_VOICE_CHANNEL
* CHANNEL_VERIFICATION_LEVEL_TOO_HIGH
* OAUTH2_APPLICATION_BOT_ABSENT
* MAXIMUM_OAUTH2_APPLICATIONS
* INVALID_OAUTH_STATE
* MISSING_PERMISSIONS
* INVALID_AUTHENTICATION_TOKEN
* NOTE_TOO_LONG
* INVALID_BULK_DELETE_QUANTITY
* CANNOT_PIN_MESSAGE_IN_OTHER_CHANNEL
* INVALID_OR_TAKEN_INVITE_CODE
* CANNOT_EXECUTE_ON_SYSTEM_MESSAGE
* INVALID_OAUTH_TOKEN
* BULK_DELETE_MESSAGE_TOO_OLD
* INVALID_FORM_BODY
* INVITE_ACCEPTED_TO_GUILD_NOT_CONTAINING_BOT
* INVALID_API_VERSION
* REACTION_BLOCKED
* RESOURCE_OVERLOADED

typedefs.name: DefaultMessageNotifications
typedefs.description:
The value set for a guild's default message notifications, e.g. `ALL`. Here are the available types:
* ALL
* MENTIONS

typedefs.name: MembershipStates
typedefs.description:
The value set for a team members's membership state:
* INVITED
* ACCEPTED

typedefs.name: WebhookTypes
typedefs.description:
The value set for a webhook's type:
* Incoming
* Channel Follower

typedefs.name: InviteResolvable
typedefs.description:
Data that can be resolved to give an invite code. This can be:
* An invite code
* An invite URL

typedefs.name: Base64Resolvable
typedefs.description:
Data that resolves to give a Base64 string, typically for image uploading. This can be:
* A Buffer
* A base64 string

typedefs.name: BufferResolvable
typedefs.description:
Data that can be resolved to give a Buffer. This can be:
* A Buffer
* The path to a local file
* A URL

typedefs.name: IntentsResolvable
typedefs.description:
Data that can be resolved to give a permission number. This can be:
* A string (see {@link Intents.FLAGS})
* An intents flag
* An instance of Intents
* An array of IntentsResolvable

typedefs.name: PermissionResolvable
typedefs.description:
Data that can be resolved to give a permission number. This can be:
* A string (see {@link Permissions.FLAGS})
* A permission number
* An instance of Permissions
* An Array of PermissionResolvable

typedefs.name: Snowflake
typedefs.description:
A Twitter snowflake, except the epoch is 2015-01-01T00:00:00.000Z
```
If we have a snowflake '266241948824764416' we can represent it as binary:

64                                          22     17     12          0
 000000111011000111100001101001000101000000  00001  00000  000000000000
      number of ms since Discord epoch       worker  pid    increment
```

typedefs.name: DeconstructedSnowflake
typedefs.description: A deconstructed snowflake.

props.name: timestamp
props.description: Timestamp the snowflake was created

props.name: date
props.description: Date the snowflake was created

props.name: workerID
props.description: Worker ID in the snowflake

props.name: processID
props.description: Process ID in the snowflake

props.name: increment
props.description: Increment in the snowflake

props.name: binary
props.description: Binary representation of the snowflake

typedefs.name: SystemChannelFlagsResolvable
typedefs.description:
Data that can be resolved to give a sytem channel flag bitfield. This can be:
* A string (see {@link SystemChannelFlags.FLAGS})
* A sytem channel flag
* An instance of SystemChannelFlags
* An Array of SystemChannelFlagsResolvable

typedefs.name: StringResolvable
typedefs.description:
Data that can be resolved to give a string. This can be:
* A string
* An array (joined with a new line delimiter to give a string)
* Any value

typedefs.name: ColorResolvable
typedefs.description:
Can be a number, hex string, an RGB array like:
```js
[255, 0, 255] // purple
```
or one of the following strings:
- `DEFAULT`
- `WHITE`
- `AQUA`
- `GREEN`
- `BLUE`
- `YELLOW`
- `PURPLE`
- `LUMINOUS_VIVID_PINK`
- `GOLD`
- `ORANGE`
- `RED`
- `GREY`
- `DARKER_GREY`
- `NAVY`
- `DARK_AQUA`
- `DARK_GREEN`
- `DARK_BLUE`
- `DARK_PURPLE`
- `DARK_VIVID_PINK`
- `DARK_GOLD`
- `DARK_ORANGE`
- `DARK_RED`
- `DARK_GREY`
- `LIGHT_GREY`
- `DARK_NAVY`
- `RANDOM`
